title: Cat. 142  The Russian Schube, 1896
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition

Levy: 160  
Transfer lithograph with scraping, drawn on white transfer paper with a grained-stone texture  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center right  
Two states; first state image size: 177 × 141 mm; second state image size: 177 × 150 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 15 (without distinguishing two states)  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 1, 151, 296, 297, 309, 318  
Stone: erased on 4 November 1903  
Selected Literature: Way and Dennis (1903), p. 87; Pennell and Pennell (1908), vol. 2, p. 169  
Lifetime Exhibitions: New York 1898 (no. 357); Chicago 1900b (no. 100); New York 1901 (no. 175)

The Russian Schube is one of four portrait lithographs (cat. 141, cat 142, cat. 143, and cat. 144) that Whistler made of his American friend Joseph Pennell in January 1896. The title of this portrait refers to the voluminous, high-collared Russian coat worn by Pennell. According to the account given by the Pennells in their 1908 biography of the artist, Whistler had planned to paint a full-length oil version of the subject, but abandoned the project when Pennell was obliged to leave London for a time and Beatrix Whistler’s health began to deteriorate. The artist may have regarded this image drawn on transfer paper as a preliminary study for that painting.

According to the Pennells, Whistler drew their portraits during afternoon visits to their flat on Ruckingham Street; some of these were made by firelight (cat. 143, cat 144, and cat. 145). After The Russian Schube was transferred to stone, Whistler made a number of revisions, both additive and subtractive, that emphasized the effect of bright sidelighting and deep cast shadows. He probably did this work at the Way offices on Wellington Street, where he spent considerable time in the early weeks of 1896 reworking earlier drawings that had been put on stone by his printers.

No doubt due to her hostility toward the Pennells, Rosalind Birnie Philip had Goulding destroy this stone in 1903, without printing a posthumous edition.

In the image as originally drawn and transferred to stone, a stray line above the right side of the collar has not yet been removed.

Glasgow: HAG, cream laid paper (285 × 227 mm). Washington: NGA, cream wove Japanese vellum (311 × 232 mm), signed, and signed and inscribed verso, in Whistler’s hand, “The Russian Schube” (Joseph Pennell) / 1st State—rare—.

Remarks: Another first-state impression is found in New York, MMA.

Revisions have been made directly on the stone. Another tier has been added to the bottom of the bookcase, thus establishing the floor line. The outlines of the coat, sleeve, and upturned collar have been clarified by scraping. Diagonal hatching has been added along the lower left edge of the coat. A few vertical lines have been added to the third tier of the bookcase. Cross-hatching has been added between the figure’s legs. The stray line above the right side of the upturned collar has been removed. Diagonal shading has been added to the right side of the coat and to the shadows at far right, extending and altering the shape of the shadow. Additions have been made to the right side of the cap, the upturned collar, and the butterfly monogram.

Chicago:AIC, cream laid paper (283 × 230 mm), signed; MWC, tan laid Japanese vellum (232 × 198 mm), signed. Glasgow: HAG (6), cream laid paper (279 × 191 mm); cream Japanese paper (287 × 222 mm), signed; cream laid paper (282 × 226 mm), signed; cream Japanese paper (288 × 221 mm); cream Japanese paper (288 × 221 mm); cream Japanese paper (288 × 221 mm). </section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The word “schube,” or “schuba,” is a transliteration of the Russian term for a heavy coat, most often made of sheepskin and traditionally worn by peasants.

The Pennells’ account reads as follows: “He told us he had taken a studio in Fitzroy Street, so that he could paint a large full-length portrait of J. in a Russian cloak—The Russian Schube—which he thought the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts might like to have. But J. was called away from London, Mrs. Whistler grew rapidly worse, and the scheme was dropped, never to be taken up again”; Pennell and Pennell (1908), vol. 2, p. 169.
